title: Case Study: Osteoporotic Vertebral Compression Fracture in an Elderly Female
clinical_history: Mrs. Judith Evans is a 72-year-old retired librarian who presented with a three-week history of worsening lower thoracic and lumbar back pain, following an episode of bending forward to lift a light box of books. She reports a dull, persistent ache across her lower back, with occasional sharp pain when changing positions. She denies any history of trauma or significant falls. Upon further questioning, Judith mentions that she has lost approximately 2 cm in height over the past year and occasionally notices that her posture is becoming stooped. There is no history of fever, weight loss, or neurological symptoms. Judith struggles to stand for long periods or walk more than 10-15 minutes due to pain, but is most uncomfortable when rising from a seated position or attempting light housework. She lives alone and relies on her daughter for more strenuous chores. Judith’s physical examination reveals local tenderness over the lower thoracic and upper lumbar vertebrae, with visible kyphosis. No neurological deficits are elicited.

nprs.affected_area: lower thoracic and lumbar spine; paraspinal muscles
secondary aching in the upper gluteal region and buttocks after prolonged standing

aggrevating_factors: Standing for longer than 10 minutes, bending forward at the waist, lifting light objects, rising from sitting, prolonged walking or carrying groceries.
picture: [Suggest image depicting localized tenderness over the T12-L2 vertebrae with mild thoracic kyphosis]
easing_factors: Resting in a reclined position, applying a heating pad to the lower back, using a firm back support cushion when sitting, paracetamol.
past_history: Diagnosed with early menopause at age 48; previous history of colles’ fracture of wrist at age 66. No significant trauma.
medical_history: Mild hypertension, well-controlled with medication; no diabetes or cardiac disease.
medications: Calcium and vitamin D supplements (started 6 months ago); Lisinopril 10 mg daily for hypertension; Paracetamol 500 mg two to three times per day for pain.
personal_history: Widow; has two adult children. Never smoked; drinks wine socially. Low dietary calcium intake historically. Occasional walker but otherwise sedentary since retirement.
imaging: Lateral spinal x-ray: reveals anterior wedge compression fracture at L1 with surrounding osteopenia; no retropulsion or spinal canal compromise.
